thread.title: Duncan passes the torch to Aldridge on Sports Illustrated cover
thread.title_full: Duncan passes the torch to Aldridge on Sports Illustrated cover - San Antonio Express-News

author: Nick Moyle
title: Duncan passes the torch to Aldridge on Sports Illustrated cover
text:

(AP ... more Image 14 of 16 Detroit Pistons forward Ersan Ilyasova (23), of Turkey, shoots against San Antonio Spurs forwards Tim Duncan (21) and LaMarcus Aldridge during the second half of a preseason NBA basketball game, Sunday, Oct. 18, 2015, in San Antonio. San Antonio won 96-92. (AP Photo/Darren Abate) Detroit Pistons forward Ersan Ilyasova (23), of Turkey, shoots against San Antonio Spurs forwards Tim Duncan (21) and LaMarcus Aldridge during the second half of a preseason NBA basketball game, Sunday, Oct. ... more Image 15 of 16 Spurs' LaMarcus Aldridge shoots against Pistons defenders as teammate Tim Duncan looks on during first half action Sunday Oct. 18, 2015 at the AT&T Center. Spurs' LaMarcus Aldridge shoots against Pistons defenders as teammate Tim Duncan looks on during first half action Sunday Oct. 18, 2015 at the AT&T Center. Photo: Edward A. Ornelas, San Antonio Express-News Image 16 of 16 Duncan passes the torch to Aldridge on Sports Illustrated cover 1 / 16 Back to Gallery Graying, stoic, Tim Duncan stands with folded arms, inches behind his heir.
LaMarcus Aldridge — labelled "The Student" by a small, upwards pointing arrow — clings to a basketball with his broad, tattooed arms, embracing it as if nothing in the world matters more, emulating the pregame ritual of his "mentor".
"New Blood in the Old School," the overlay reads.
Sports Illustrated regional covers for the NBA's coming season have been released this year with a "passing the torch" theme, and Duncan and Aldridge embody that notion perhaps better than any tandem in the league.
The league's elder statesman, a two-time MVP, five-time champion and unequivocally one of the greatest players in NBA history, alongside the native son now returned to become the Spurs' big man of the future — what Duncan once was nearly two decades ago.
The three other regional covers feature similar duos, though none are as inspired a choice as the Duncan-Aldridge pairing.
Kevin Garnett and Karl-Anthony Towns represent the Timberwolves, but Garnett made excursions elsewhere during his career and his time as a dominant force is long over.
Kobe Bryant and D'Angello Russell feature for the Lakers, but does anyone truly believe the Mamba is content to concede his alpha dog status to anyone, let alone a rookie?
Miami's tandem of Dwayne Wade and Justise Winslow should develop a fruitful relationship, but Wade has a few years left as the face of the franchise, if he can stay on the court.
Duncan is the only one of the elders who either has a torch to pass or is truly willing to hand it over.
The more pressing matter, though, is the supposed Sports Illustrated cover jinx.
The jinx dates back to Aug. 16, 1954, the very first issue.
In the midst of a nine-game winning streak, Braves third baseman Eddie Mathews became the first man to appear on the cover.
His reward? The streak was broken, and soon, so was his hand.
This year alone the cover has brought ill fortune upon the Oregon Ducks football team, Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball team, Seattle Seahawks, Cleveland Indians, Washington Nationals, Seattle Mariners and Serena Williams.
That might worry a legion of Spurs fans, but it won't rattle Gregg Popovich in the least.
"Are you superstitious in anyway?" a fan once asked Pops.
His answer?
"Absolutely not, in no way whatsoever. It's a waste of time."
